A friend of mine sent me this YouTube video link - http://youtu.be/cl5ZVvTI6qk - where they had this demo model all printed in one go on their 3D printer. I watched the video a few times and converted it to a CAD model for our UP! Plus 3D printer. It's a very fun toy to play with, and good example of how 3D printers can make things that no other machines can make. :)

UPDATE: print with premium ABS filament and have the fan blowing at the model so the filament hardens up faster. That way the support will be a lot easier to remove. I've done a simplified version and another more modified version. Flipping Model (Simple) - rectangular shape
Flipping Model (Modified) - more complicated shape with patterns They need to be printed flat, exactly as how the files were uploaded, to make the hinges strong enough. If printed vertically, the hinges may fail. Hope you like them!

comments.text: I have had nothing but fits trying to print this.  Can you please tell me what you are using for a layer height?  Everything looks really nice until I try to separate the pieces.  When I look at my slicing before I print I have layers that I think should have support but instead have nothing at all in the layer.   I am going to attempt to print it again with a smaller tip and I'll drop my temperature a bit to try and get it to not bond as well, but if I can slice it at the same interval you did I think that should help.  I sliced the first model at .2 and ran with a .5 tip.  Thanks a bunch!
comments.author: Bschulth

comments.text: Just had a thought...maybe scale the model up a bit bigger so the gaps are big enough for your software to recognise and build support in between?
comments.author: Bschulth

comments.text: Hi I don't know what printer you printed on but I designed the model to suit my UP Plus printer. 0.25mm resolution. Normal speed. Support 2 layers. Support angle 10 degrees.
comments.author: Bschulth

comments.text:
I do not know what to do.
I have printed it with 100% scale but the piece is almost a brick.
comments.author: idea_beans

comments.text: It depends on what slicer or printer you're using. The support in between the parts need to be thin and loose. If you use S3D then it's possible to adjust the density of support. If you use UP Plus printer, it'll print perfectly without you doing too much fiddling with settings.
comments.author: Carolinefranco

comments.text:
I am using a printer bq hephestos prusa i3 with Cura.
I think that the problem is not the support since it is already set to be with a very low density... I have tried with 20% and 10% density.
Somehow, when this file is printed with my settings and printer, there is no gap between the pieces. They are overlaping.
But when i look at the layers using Cura, I can see all of them.
Any guess? :(
Thanks for your help!!
comments.author: idea_beans

comments.text: When I drew the CAD model I had allowed a 0.6mm gap between all the parts, horizontally and vertically. On my UP Plus printer it prints a very thin layer of support in between the parts. Very easy to remove afterwards. I've printed 2 last night, one at the uploaded size and the other scaled up 110%. No trouble removing the support at all. :)

This is a kind of 'reverse engineered from pictures' Mantis replica rendered in OpenScad.
It's my first 'beyond basics' OpenScad project, with an attempt to be parametric about the various sizes (though as noted, the dimensions are better read as tenths of an inch), and there are x,y,z movements adjustable at the top of the file along with limits (though the nice thing is it won't break if you push it too far:)  ).
I've got the right side commented out, just for visibility.
I did develop a far better feel for 'how these things work' by doing this, and though I can't say that my programming skills have been thoroughly developed, it's been fun to do, the cost of all the entertainment was precisely right :)  and I've got to thank OpenScad for the past three days of frustration and fun.
I might get rid of even more egregious errors in the file later on...
Now, if I can just get back to physical objects....

If you don't have OpenScad, it's readily available as a free download.
The examples provided with it give a sort of soft-start for programming objects.

title: Agatha's Clank
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A model based on Agatha's little Clank from the Girl Genius webcomic (http://girlgeniusonline.com/). It has posable arms and legs. The model's eye can be positioned to look in various directions. Finally, the winding knob on the top will turn. With a little practice, you should be able to stand the little clank. I've marked it as non-commercial because the original concept is not mine, and I think the creators of Girl Genius should get a say in commercial applications.

The clank-limbs.stl file should be printed with 0.30mm thickness, 1 shell, and 60% infill.
All other plates are printed with 0.30mm thickness, 2 shells, and 35% infill. Assembly of the model is not 100% obvious until you've done it once. Print all of the
pieces and clean up the parts, if necessary.
  • From the clank-limbs.stl, take the round shoulder objects and the arms (long rectangles
    pinchers on the end).
  • Cut two pieces of 3mm filament a little less than 1cm long.
  • Apply a small amount of acetone or glue to the filament and the openings on the arm and
    shoulder.
  • Use the filament to attach the shoulder to the arm.
  • Repeat for the other arm.
  • Carefully smooth out any droopy stuff in the cavity in the back piece.
  • Place the flat part of the eye (the part without the hole) in the cavity in back piece.
  • Push the front piece on over the eye until the eye snaps into the front piece and the
    back and front are flat together.
  • Separate the back and front.
  • Place the cone part of the stem into the cavity in the top of the back.
  • Brush acetone or glue on the flat portions of the back and front. Be careful not to
    get any on or too close to the eye or stem.
  • Line up the front and back. Stick them together and hold until the joint sets.
  • Brush a little acetone or glue around the joint being careful not to get any on the
    stem or into the gaps where the arms and legs go.
  • After everything is dry, snap the arms and legs into the appropriate holes.
  • Enjoy.
    • For a little nicer effect, paint the eye before assembling the clank.

author: gwadej

description.text:
Trying to smoke less i set myself a limit of 4 cigarettes per day. That didn't work well since i needed to carry my tobacco and filters with me for rolling 'em up because i couldn't carry pre rolled ones.
So i fumbled around with openscad some more and this is the result. Now i can pre roll some and won't go over my daily limit so easily... The lid is quite hard to get on and even harder to get off but after putting it on and off a number of times it works perfect.
Since i modeled it too small you need to print it 10 times it's size. I'll upload the scad files too in case someone wants to edit anything but for me and for now it works as it is...
edit: Had no rest unless this was perfect. Remodeled it completely. Now there shouldn't any scaling be necessary plus the corners look better... Maybe someone can comment on it's printability...
and again a new version: didn't check the smaller corner radius in v2. made it way bigger in v3, just don't know how it'll print. there's not much material left. Will print myself and add images...

Print 10 times it's scale in Cura or whatever you're using... and flip the upper Part on Y-Axis.
edit: 2nd version should be printable as it is. So should v3...

comments.text: Try adding small lids to prevent from sliding open.

comments.text: Here's hoping to smoke less too. Thank U !

It took a day to realize that the corners were way smaller/sharper than in v1 so i did set some variables and created v3, which has way rounder corners than v1 and v2...

I had a look at some of the prop guard designs, but thought they weighed too much and also had a problem where they would strip the motor wires as they were slid on.
RC-King's version has been designed to be both light weight and springy with more than sufficient clearance for the motor wires.
You can download and print these here or visit our website to buy them out right. http://www.rc-king.co.za/cheerson-cx-10-spares/427-cheerson-cx-10-prop-guards.html

I print these at a 0.1mm height using florescent green ABS. The light combines in the material and give a great look. I typically print 5 at a time to ensure each layer gets a chance to cool down.
You want to make sure that your printer is well calibrated as this is an extremely small print. Please note that the new Cheerson's have a slightly larger foot. You may have to scale up to 110%

title: Base for Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 in Otter box and telemetry radio

description.text:
The base has room for an APM ground station telemetry radio with USB adapter and an antenna extending from the corner. It also has loops for straps so that it can be readily carried in a convenient position.
The case for the telemetry radio is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:165889 I use it with the DroidPlanner software: https://github.com/DroidPlanner/droidplanner
The Otter box is in no way crucial for the concept, and I believe it should be a reasonable effort to convert the OpenScad design for use with a bare tablet instead, or indeed for other Android tablets.
The length of this design is exactly 200mm. I was able to print it on a 200x200mm Bukobot printer by temporarily setting the platform to 206x206mm in Cura.

comments.text: Insulin is a hormone normally produced by the pancreas to regulate blood sugar. For an individual with Type 1 Diabetes, their pancreas no longer produces insulin, and therefore biosynthesized insulin is injected to regulate blood sugar. Because insulin is a protein, it denatures in high heat and refrigerated storage before use is recommended to prolong shelf-life.

author: rogwabbit

description.text:
Here is a 50mm calibration angle used for calibrating your machine. This is designed to be small and fast to get calibrated quickly! I printed it on my Printrbot Jr. The outer X and Y are 50mm.
The inner spaces are 30mm.
The whole thing is 5mm thick.
Each arm is 10mm wide. Look at the instructions -->

This works pretty well. Within 2 prints I had my printrbot jr fully calibrated to .1mm tolerances. Well enough to print an iPhone case that fits. I've included the STL and a sketchup file if you want to mess with it.
In case your new to calibration, I'm going to break it all down for you: Usually in the custom Start g-code area in Slic3r you'll have 4 calibration values for X,Y,Z and E for Extruder.
If you don't have custom g-code in there, you'll want to add it. Here is what mine looks like for a printrbot jr. G28 ; home all axes
M92 X63.0242 ; calibrate X
M92 Y62.7669 ; calibrate Y
M92 Z2071.4959 ; calibrate Z
M92 E650 ; calibrate E You are welcome to use these as starter values. Just paste them into the custom g-code section of slic3r. (note: direct drive extruder starter value should be M92 E100) To calibrate you first print this puppy out. When it's finished you'll want to measure it with a caliper, digital preferred. How close to 50mm for X and Y are you? X is the side to side when facing your printer. Y is the back and forth. And Z is the up and down. Bust out your calculator and run this calculation:
(Don't be scared, it's easy)
First multiply the current value of X by the length in the STL, 50mm. Then divide that number by what you actually measured. The result is your new custom-gcode value for X.
So in my case, say I measured the X of my print to be 48.25mm, I would do 63.0242 X 50mm = 3151.21 (current X value times the value in the model)
THEN
3151.21 / 48.25 = 65.3101 (result divided by my measurement)
So in my custom G-Code I would replace 63.0242 with 65.3101
Do the same for Y, and it works for Z too! Re-slice by exporting it to G-Code and reprint that bad boy. Check your measurements, and do it all over again if you are off by more than .5mm I hope this has been helpful, I know it's tough when you are first getting started.
For speed, I printed this object with 1 perimeter, 1 shell top and bottom, and infill of .1 (10%)

description.text:
Print two of these, mount 608ZZ bearings and put on M8 rod. For use with any holder.
The plug is conical with smallest diameter of 48mm and biggest 52mm, so it might fit into other spools than mine.
Print with desired setting, no support needed. I recommend infill at least 25%.

When building cages for rabbits out of various forms of wire mesh, you often find a need for raising the mesh slightly off the surface. My wife, Debbie Campbell, came up with the idea of these little standoffs to
make cleaning the bunny areas a little easier. UPDATE: I reorganized these old scad files into a much cleaner implementation that uses one scad file to generate the two STL files.
Print one corner piece for each corner you need to support. Print the straight pieces for long runs or for corners that are part of doors.

description.text:
A normal "tire iron" used with bikes to put tires on the rim or to remove tires from the rim.  
Make sure you don't have any sharp edges on your print to reduce the chance of puncturing your tire.

Mandalorian gauntlets, (eg Boba Fett) often attach using piano hinges that have been taken apart and the pin inserted to clasp them together over ones hand. These are similar in design but are adjustable, and if printed in ABS will glue to vacformed ABS costume gauntlets eliminating the need to use Velcro or rivet piano hinges
Print one set for each gauntlet

comments.text: Love, love, love these. I built my son a 501st 3rd tier Boba Fett. We bought the Blaster and gauntlet rocket from you and were very impressed with the quality. I built the body of the gauntlets from scratch. I used piano hinges on the closed side and velcro on the opening. I have never been satisfied with the dependability of the velcro, but didn't have a better solution. Until I found this Thing, and when I saw it was yours, I knew I would be happy with it. And I didn't even have a 3D printer yet, so this was on my To Do list as I was waiting for my printer to arrive. After just a few test prints to feel I knew what I was doing, this was my first print with a purpose. They came out great, only minor sanding needed. And the difference this made in the fit of the gauntlets and the confidence that they wouldn't need fixing in the middle of a Con, was 100%. Thanks so much for sharing this, Very, very impressed.....again.

remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 Vanilla Adjustable Y Axis Endstop Holder

title: P3Steel / Prusa i3 adjustable configurable Y endstop holder

description.text:
This is a remix of thing #335726 by greymatterdroppings (Matt). It is an adjustable, configurable Y endstop holder.
It can be adjusted for height and depth allowing for precise adjustment of the Y home position, and it can be configured for use with either any Prusa i3 variant with 8mm rods (e.g. the Prusa i3 vanilla or the improved Twelvepro Prusa i3), or the P3Steel. Also, the limit switch is attached to a small carrier and two carrier choices are possible: either the Makerbot a.k.a Sainsmart mechanical switch, or a plain miniature limit switch.
OpenSCAD sources (with proper attribution to Matt) are included so this part can be edited to taste.

No bridges! Can be printed in ABS or PLA. 35% infill works for me and results in strong parts. Requires 1 x M3 12mm hex bolt and nyloc nut for the P3Steel mount. Requires 4 x M3 16mm or 20mm bolts, washers and nyloc nuts for the adjustable parts. Requires a nylon zip tie or 2 x M3 12mm bolts and nyloc nuts depending on carrier choice.

comments.text:
Ok, now I get it, sorry! Take a look at the very end of the OpenSCAD file and you'll notice that only one module call is uncommented, this is done so that each part gets generated separately, but from the same OpenSCAD file. Just uncomment one module call at a time and generate the STLs that you need/want (I believe in your case you only need to change the P3Steel_horiz part).
I have adopted the convention to have always first the parameters, then the modules, and finally the module calls in all my OpenSCAD files.
comments.author: Llama16

comments.text:
Hi Matt,
Thanks for the elegantly simple and functional original design! It's been rock solid up until now and it's definitely the best (imnsho) Y endstop for the very specific requirements of the P3Steel.
It's one of those install, adjust and forget parts. So much so that I am using the same parts for both my P3Steel printers and also for my under construction Prusa i3 Twelvepro.

I like the filament guide bar by tdiggs, but it just wasnt robust enough for me. The end supports kept snapping. So this is a more robust version of the same idea. Improvements:

  • Larger end supports with larger diameter connectors which are less likely to snap off.

  • The inner surfaces of the guide bar are rounded slightly to allow the filament to move through more smoothly

title: RPi and camera support for Printrbot Simple Maker's Kit (1405)

description.header: Check out the 2nd version of this project

description.text: The Printrbot Simple Maker's Kit is a wonderful small 3D printer with loads of potential. Octoprint has a special distribution for the Raspberry Pi called OctoPi which allows one to load STL parts, print and make time lapse videos via local network and free your computer from the burden of being attached to the printer for while it's printring. To mount parts to the printer more securely I made some supports that attach to the existing screws on the printer, the screws are long enough to hold the supports and still reach the nuts. The support for the RPi is for the model B, not the more recent B+. The stock RPi camera cable isn't long enough so I ordered a longer one from DealExtreme (although it needs to be modified). The camera has its focus set to infinity by default you need to break the glue inside it by rotating the lens a little bit to adjust the focus as needed, otherwise you'll get a very blurry image. Since the Printrbot USB port is so close to the RPi USB port I also ordered a tiny micro-USB cable. To complete the set I added a USB Wi-Fi dongle on the RPi so I can control it wirelessly from anywhere in the house from any device. Note that since the camera is mounted on the base the time-lapse videos aren't very good as the part keeps moving from frame to frame, a better solution would be to attach it on the print-bed, this was done in the 2nd version of this project.

comments.text: Has anyone tested if this works on the metal simple?
comments.author: justinwzig

comments.text: This is to be used with the Maker's Kit (1405). The printer's screws are long enough so you don't need any additional fixation points and since on the metal simple the holes aren't in the same place as the kit it probably won't work.
comments.author: justinwzig

comments.text: What modification was necessary for the cable?
comments.author: bobe99

comments.text: They claim it's compatible with the RPi camera but the camera needs a type-B cable with connections on either side of the cable, the one they sell has them on the same side (type-A). I removed the blue part and bent the cable over before inserting it in the camera. I left a review on the product page that explains the problem with images: http://club.dx.com/reviews/278772/593555.
comments.author: bobe99

author: schrotti

title: Mounting system for Raspberry Pi camera

description.text:
This assembly is a combination of a slim case for the pi camera and a few mounting details that makes it possible to mount the camera at virtually any angle.
The two arms called mount2 and mount2r are right and left variants of the upper mounting arm. You will only need one of them.
In the picture the fixture is mounted using mount3 or mount4. These are specialized click mounts for the Velleman K8200/3Drag, If you do not intend to mount the camera on a K8200 you can mount the fixture in any m3 hole that is 2-3mm deep. Standard Allen M3 bolts should be used for best result.
The parts are made to be printed with relative good resolution. I used 0.2mm which worked well for me. The holes are specified so that M3 bolts should be a very tight fit to provide a stable mount. It should not be possible to just drop the bolts in. You should have to screw them into the holes.
This is a remix from my camera case for the Raspberry Pi Camera module with mounting holes. It can be found separately here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:533865

title: Sodastream to normal soda bottle adapter

description.text:
This adapter makes it possible to connect standard soda bottles directly to Sodastream carbonator. Use a seal from a normal bottle cap, an o-ring or something else to properly seal the soda bottle properly to the adapter.  
Model is made with a little tolerance. It printed perfect as is on a Robox from PLA. I assume it's safe to use this in the kitchen as it doesn't get in touch with the water being carbonated.  
Original FreeCAD file is included in case modifications for a different kind of bottle thread or neck needs to be done.

comments.text: I had an adapter made based on this file. What I noticed right from the start, even before using the adapter, is the fact that the inner thread (the one for the bottle) was very thin and low. Moreover, the material (SLS-PA2200) was a little rough, preventing gas-tightness. The choice for this material is probably my fault as newbie. I had to add a rubber washer to get CO2 tightness. Anyway, the thin thread was not able to hold the bottle pressure. The CO2 pressure (only after 3 short CO2 bursts) simply blasted the bottle off the thin thread. Any suggestions? Did the material I chose not allow for the proper thickness and height? What would have been the right material? Hints very much appreciated.
comments.author: m273dc

comments.text: Hey guys, I just got finished printing mine out and it fits great, the only word of advice I have is to use silicone caulking as the seal, I just pushed it into the inside corner where the bottle goes in and put just a bit of caulking all the way around, it works great
comments.author: DBurke

comments.text:
I made one and it works, even without a seal.
The Sodastream thread fits very well, and the upper end seals airtight.
The inner plate for the PET bottle isn't completely airtight without a sealing, but it's good enough.
But the inner thread is very shallow, I doubt that it'll last long. Could you make it thicker?
Also it might be a good idea to provide a version with a wider diameter for the Sadastream thread, so that it screws in with a lot of friction, for people that want to leave the adapter always in the machine, and don't want it to come put when they unscrew the bottle.
Thanks for your work. Great thing!
comments.author: karlkloss

comments.text: I downloaded this sodastream adapter file (sodastream_to_standard_soda_bottle_adapter_v4.stl) spent $20 + $5 shipping. Waited 3 weeks to get it. The drawing looked flaky to begin with. The inside view of the model where the standard soda bottle threads into the adapter has very shallow threads. It won't hold Coke bottle threads, It won't hold Pepsi bottle threads either. This drawing WON'T HOLD any bottle for that matter. I would not trust even a version 5 of this 'thing'. It would have been nice 'thing' if it worked but sadly it don't so save your money and time.

author: nischi

description.text:
This greatly reduces the noise from the extruder motor. The wooden backplane of the Ultimaker did act like a drum. To find out how much noise this upgrade can remove, carefully un-hook the feeder while printing, and hold it in your hand. Answer: it makes a huge difference. Update1: separate, much better holder for the bowden coupling, and other tweaks.
Update2: upper hook should withstand PLA creep better.

Print the "feeder_suspension" STL twice, the "middlepiece" and the "coupling holder" once.  
I sliced with Cura, with two walls, infill 20% and 30% both worked fine. I think natural (clear) PLA has the best spring properties, but I have printed the second version in gray PLA, and it works fine too. I had to turn the bearing holes through sandpaper because there was a printer blob inside.  
Note: the new material feeder will tilt slightly to the side, and follow the movements of the printer head. It's probably a good thing, because it relieves some tension that was previously in the bowden cable. But it sometimes adds a new clicking noise, when the grip on the wooden back plate shifts during printing. Also, the filament seems to make slight rattling sounds when it is not feeding straight now.  
Known problems: PLA under mechanical load will creep over time, even at room temperature. Check and re-tighten the motor screws after the first few weeks. The upper hooks were a weak point, I had them slide out after a few months (impossible with a fresh print), so watch out. The latest version should be better, but only time will tell for sure.  You can fix the upper hooks with a zip tie or packing cord through the wooden back holes to prevent it.  
The design was done in Blender using 2D splines. You could probably extract them from the .blend file and laser-cut it. It was based on the laser-cut drawings by Ultimaker. There isn't much left of the original, so I dropped the silly non-commercial license restriction. Please consider my design public domain. Attribution is appreciated but not required.

title: Swinging Snowman, PLA Spring Motor Style
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Winter is here (well, at least where I live) and snow is on its way (well, for some of us) and how best to celebrate the cold wintry weather by staying inside and printing a Swinging Snowman, PLA Spring Motor style! Complete with hat, eyes, earmuffs, buttons and a bow tie, this steampunk stylized thing utilizes a PLA Spring Motor (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:402412) and a clockwork style escapement mechanism to swing the snowman a couple of minutes or more per winding. No batteries, power supplies, motors, bearings or bushings are required. Video of prototype is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tj2_3SADafo&list=UUv_zm49u-RjnCJVwhUO-ecA&index=1. Designed using Sketchup 8, and printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" (.2mm layer height, 2 shells, 10% infill) settings.

Carefully study "Assembly.skp". Note that the .skp file should be used as an assembly diagram and not be used to print parts as the parts in the .skp file may not be the final parts as found in the .stl files.  
Print all PLA parts from the .stl files. Print "Knob.stl" and "Spring.stl" with Makerware "Standard" settings modified for 100% infill, the remaining parts using Makerware "Standard" settings with the default infill. Due to the balance requirements of this thing, I do not recommend changing the layer height, shells and/or infill settings as the performance of your build may vary significantly.  
Test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. all parts as necessary for smooth movement of moving surfaces, and tight fit for non moving surfaces. Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, filing and/or sanding will be required.  
Assemble as per "Assembly.skp".  Note that "Hat.stl" and "Button.stl" were glued in place with a small dot of thick cyanoacrylate glue.   
Lubricate moving surfaces with light machine oil.  
Comment if questions.  
Hope you like it!

This is my second version of a simple snap-on case for the Hacklace2. It is smaller then the previous version (half the height), and it comes with rounded corners. There are different versions available:
  • Breakout for both headers (programming and extension)
  • Breakout only for the programming header
  • Not header breakouts at all
Just print it as in the STL file. Some "force" is needed to install the Hacklace2 into the case (snap-on).

This is an adaptation of the Platform lift I downloaded last week to work with Legos. This one has some changes that make it work better. Uses MG90S Micro Servo. Platform size 8x9 small Lego blocks, platform goes 8 blocks back and 7 blocks high. Here is a YouTube video of it working https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iWzJx6KI-wc
There are some different gears to play with, a 15 tooth is in the video. 13 and 14 tooth will not travel quite as far, but will lift more.

I had to build in some support for the platform and the lift arm. They will break away easily and give you a better build.
The arms are held in place by #15 brad nails cut down. Everything else uses #4x1/4" and #4x3/8" sheet metal screws. Servo screws will come with servo.
You will have to drill out the gear to .182" and push on the servo to cut teeth in gear. Once teeth are cut you can pop gear on and off to get the right timing of the lift arm and travel both ways. There is a 13 and 14 tooth gear also if you want to gear it down to lift more. But smaller drive gear will not let arm travel as far.
Servo holder and adjuster will give you room to up and down to adjust servo to get good mesh with gears.
The lift arm shaft needs to be cleaned up smooth and round. Screw the lift arm caps on the base and line drill to .182" or bigger if needed, so the arm moves freely.
Lots of filing and fitting to make it work nice. The platform printed pretty warped on bottom. Sanded it down flat on flat surface and filed edges so it looks better.
Did the best I could to make them fit Lego blocks. Have fun!

An attachment for a electric screwdriver for twisting pairs of wires together.
We made this device so we could tidy up wire pairs using an electric screwdriver.
It uses a small retaining M3 screw to clamp the wires in place and has a simple hex rod to fit into standard screwdriver fittings. To use simply put the wires into the central holes and tighten the screw (not too tight or else you'll crush the wires).
Hold or secure the other end of the wires maintaining tension on the wires, and then turn on the screwdriver until wires are twisted to your satisfaction. Feel free to leave a comment.

Print at 20% fill or higher.
Requires M3 screw (5mm or more grub screw or 10mm or more normal) and M3 nut.
Put the nut into the square hole in the bottom and put the screw partially into the nut through the hole in the side leaving room for the wires.

author: EricXu1235

title: Parametric Horizontal Spool Roller (for rostock-mini, Octave, MakerGear, othes)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a parametric horizontal spool roller. I created it to hold a spool of filament above the top frame of my (slightly modified) rostock-mini, but it can be used to hold a spool horizontally above any flat surface.
The STL files provided work with spools that have 31mm and 51mm holes (Octave and MakerGear). If your spool(s) have different sized holes, you will need to modify the SCAD file and re-generate the STL files. (You can also make the arms longer or shorter, and make the base/shield a different height). The smaller spool hole size is built into the parts, and the larger hole size is accomodated by an "expansion ring" that is held by the shield piece at the base until it is needed.

I recommend that you print the testPrint.stl file first to make sure that everything will fit your spools, 608 bearings, and that the expansion ring will fit snugly, but not too tight, over the inner ring. If anything doesn't fit, adjust the "calib" setting (or the small/large spool radius) in the SCAD file and re-print. Read the comments in the SCAD file to figure out which ring should fit over what other rings/parts. In adition to the printed parts, you will need two 608 (roller skate) bearings, a M8 (or 5/16) bolt of the appropriate length, with 4 nuts and optionally 4 washers. With the provided STL files, I mounted my spool holder such that a NEMA 17 stepper could fit under it horizontally, and bolted it to a 0.25 inch (6.35mm) thick sheet of acrylic, and I used a 100 mm bolt (4 inches) but could have gotten away with a 90mm bolt. If you want to mount it closer to the mounting surface, either omit the shield piece, or edit the .SCAD file and re-create the STL files after shortening the shield. (and use a shorter bolt unless you don't mind that it pokes out the bottom). Use two nuts tightened against each other under the bottom bearing to hold the head up. Then use a nut and washer above the mounting plate, and a washer and nut under the mounting plate. (You will have to drill an 8mm or 5/16 hole in whatever is your mounting plate.) My specific order of assembly is:
  • Insert the two 608 bearings, one into the piece with arms, and the other into the "sr bottom" (which may actually go on the top!)
  • Stick your bolt through the "sr bottom" piece with the bolt head against the plastic part, through the 608 bearing and out the top.
  • Thread the bolt through the part with the arms, leaving the bearing at the bottom visible.
  • Place a washer next to the bearing.
  • Thread two nuts down to the washer, barely finger tight.
  • Tighten the two nuts against each other to keep the "head" of the spool roller from moving down the bolt (when it spins it may want to loosen a single nut). DO NOT APPLY PRESSURE between the two bearings! The head should have a 0.1mm "gap" so that it spins easily. If it starts to be hard to turn you've tighetened it too much! Tighten the two nuts against each other, not up towards the bolt head.
  • Place a nut and washer farther down the bolt, at the appropriate location for how high you want your "head" to be above the mounting plate, taking into account the thickness of the shield (if you are using it.)
  • (optionally) Place the shield piece on the bolt, then push the bolt against your mounting plate. Make sure you are happy with the location, and drill a hole in your mounting plate. Push the bolt through the hole and afix it with a washer/nut on the other side.
    • Possible Modifications:
    You probably don't even need the washers if your nuts are the right size. You can of course reverse the bolt so that the head is under the bottom mounting plate and the extra threads stick out of a nut on the top. You can also turn the entire "head" of the spool roller upside down, such that the SR_bottom piece is actually upside down below the arm piece, hiding the double nut arrangement. But you'll need a socket to tighten them up, and tightening them against each other is harder. This is actually how I had originally designed the part to work (hence the SR Bottom name), but then I realized that my sense of aesthetics was upside down and it looked better if I fliped it....go figure.

If you own a LandRover Defender and a 3D printer then this might be of interest. This cup holder fits into one of the spare switch slots on the centre console.

The holder needs a firm push to click into place, but once it is in, it is very stable and secure.
The holder is off-set to the right, in order to avoid hitting it when slecting fifth gear. If you drive a left-hand-drive Defender, you may need to mirror the part so the off-set is the other way (or you could just turn it up-side down, but I haven't tried this).
With an 80mm diameter ring, it fits most takeaway coffee cups.....

title: Frame of resistance wire - hot bed

description.text:
A frame for 5 resistance wires which is a solution for the hot bed.
The second frame is upgraded, it fits better to my Reprap.

This is a frame for the hot bed of Mendel Prusa machine. This frame is for 5 resistance wires. Wires are mounted between 2 frames. They are mounted indirectly. You have to use ceramic beads to mount wires in frames. Each frame is mounted by 2 bolts to a wooden plate which is connected with guide bars by bearings as usual.
Reflective material under wires will short the heating time, but mind that your glass can break because of this as i shown on the pictures.

comments.text: I've tried to put some reflective metal on the bottom part of my bed. The results were disasterous. You can observe my broken glass on the picture. This happened twice, that's why i abandoned this idea. Sorry moyboyufl. But heating itself were more effective I think. Temperature probably have been raising much faster, what was the reason of broken glass.
comments.author: Muddler

comments.text:
I have never thought about emulate the toaster, but yes - my bed look very similar. I have chosen the easiest way to make hot bed, i.e. glass which is flat for sure. I couldn't find good aluminum plate, that is why I've mounted glass only. Also the resistance wires were pretty easy for me to get/buy. I have been looking for resistors but I've failed to obtain proper ones. To prevent the melting... yes I had to tape the bottom and the frame with insulating tape. The glass is also taped from the top.
Thanks for your tips moyboyufl. I will probably use them during next maintains.
For now, my bed works and as the thermistor shows, it allows me to reach 120 degrees. What is more, I can easily set the bed parallel to the head, which was problematic which my previous solution - hand made frame of textolite.
comments.author: Muddler

comments.text: Are you trying to emulate the radiative heating of a toaster? If so, be aware that radiation is orders of magnitude less efficient Than conductive heating. Are you trying to heat the bed or the part directly. Either way, you should cover the wood on the bottom with a reflective metal. Foil is a start but the more reflective the better. If you are trying to heat the bed, I'd suggest using an aluminum bed painted black on the side of the heat. Using just glass will probably just let the radiation pass through, depending on the type of glass. You can test this out by putting your hand a few inches from glass to sew if you can feel the radiation. The glass will be heated by convection, which is the moving air around the coils touching the bed, so you'd probably want to insulate the bottom to trap as much heat as you can without melting your printed coil holders. If radiation is your main heat transfer method, you might find mixed results with different colors, black being the most effective. I'm really curious to see your results. Good luck!

author: mathgrrl

description.text:
Delta-Pi is a Rostock delta style 3D Printer.
It is still in prototype phase but feel free to follow along and build your own.
This design is still experimental. Build at your own risk
Official web page: http://reprap.org/wiki/Delta-Pi
Other Links:
YoutTube Playlist
Source files and Bill of Materials
Flickr Photo Set

A full BOM has been posted to github.
The PDF's show the assembly details.
The "edrw" files can be viewed with a free viewer available here
The towers use 19mm(3/4") or 20mm square tube 670mm long. 180 grit polished stainless tube is recommended. Choose the 19 or 20mm version of parts as appropriate.
Each tower needs 10 pieces of 623ZZ Deep groove ball bearings. There are 8 pieces in each carriage and 2 for each idler pulley so 30 pieces in total.
The arms use carbon fibre tube with 6mm OD. The tube I used had 5mm ID and was pulltruded tube. Use some 2 part epoxy to glue them together. All 6 arms need to be the same length (250mm) as close as possible so make a jig and "set" the length as you glue them. The carbon tube length is 206mm
Nothing in the design should be difficult to obtain locally. If you get stuck http://www.makershop.co.nz is my website and we will ship internationally. All the parts except fasteners and printed parts are listed there but no kitset options - yet.
Update 11 March 2013
Added STLs for use with 20mm tube. Some countries 20mm is easier to get than 3/4 inch (19mm).
Update 15 March 2013
The Delta-Pi successfully printed its first parts. After ironing out a construction defect in the hot-end we printed an Octocat. Print quality wasn't too bad. I need to add a cooling fan and there were a few cobwebs to clean off but it was a success.
Update 5 April 2013
Added revised top and bottom boards and hot end mounting parts.
Update 3 November 2013
Added a new hub design including a touch probe for automated bed levelling.
Update 7 March 2014
Added Repetier firmware config.h file for ver 0.91

comments.text:
I don't think the use of two small 623ZZ ball bearings per idler pulley is a flaw at all, it's just a design choice. I am also quite comfortable with using eight small 623ZZ ball bearings per carriage, perhaps you are forgetting that these small ball bearings can cost as little as $0.12 each.
"ANYWAY" I took a look at your printed corner roller which uses a single slightly larger 624ZZ bearing and it would require a complete redesign of the carriage. I am not even sure one can build a simple loading structure for your roller and there is also the issue of printed rollers not quite having the same precision and wear resistance as steel ball bearings. All things considered I think your corner roller will remain in the domain of "unproven concepts" for quite some time, whereas the Delta-Pi carriage design is already proven to work.
Posting a comment and calling a proven design "flawed" as you did is not only incorrect but rather impolite too.

comments.author: MikeP-NZ

comments.text:
If you are going with the original design then the make sure you don't drill out the holes for the pivot bolts in the arms. You need to screw the bolts through to keep the linkages tight and free from play. But don't do the bolts up tight because the linkages need to be pivoting freely without too much friction. They will last quite a while but too soon you'll find that there is play appearing in the joints and it becomes very noisy when that happens.
The move to ball joints is very easy. The carriages and hub are the same.

comments.text: Your best bet is to run my config.h file through Repetier online editor. Take some time to read and understand what the selections mean. There are many possible combinations of hardware and settings so it is rare for one person's config.h to work for another person without making some changes. If you are still stuck then try asking specific questions on one of the forums. Questions like "Can you help me?" generally get ignored.

comments.author: MikeP-NZ

comments.text:
Maximum print speed is more a function of the hot-end design than the rest of the printer.
I usually print at less than 80mm/s. Not to say it can't go faster, I just prefer quality output over speed.
Rapid moves of 300mm/s are OK.
Faster than that and you run into the limitations of the pulse frequency that can be output by an Arduino Mega.

comments.text: yeah i have been looking at that website and ive been trying to raise the Delta Radius to lower the printhead. i was doing it in intervals of 10mm but that didnt seem to lower the center at all it just seemed to throw off the coordinates of other points , would changing it by 1mm or 2mm really fix an offset of 15mm?
comments.author: turuncu

comments.text:
The delta radius value has no effect at the center. The effect is to raise or lower the outer points.
You set the center by adjusting Z_MAX_LENGTH first then adjust DELTA_RADIUS so that the height at the edge is correct.
Don't forget that depending on which firmware and which version you use one or both of these values from configuration.h may be overridden by a value from EEPROM
comments.author: Stuartblarg

comments.text: Yeah, i've been making sure to change the Z max length in the eeprom and not the firmware, partly because the firmware doesn't seem to want to let me turn the eeprom off. Ok well i'll do some measuring and tinkering and see what i come up with.

comments.text: each time you change delta radius, you need to change max z height (or leave it the same and re-do the endstop calibration. that blog suggests changing endstop values)

comments.text:
hmm, well i sort of got the 3 outside points and the middle level but this required upping the printer radius from 175 to 250 which offset the delta radius to 199 which is causing all sorts of movement problems and isnt even staying level constantly around the board.
So im thinking the problem is elsewhere, im just not sure where is would be. I dont think i did many major changes to the firmware when i got it off Mike all those months ago but the 15mm drop off seems a bit too consistent for a hardware issue
comments.author: turuncu

comments.text: Your issue sounds very similar to my old issue. Do a G1 X0 Y0 Z1 then G1 X90 Y0 Z1 and again G1 X0 Y0 Z1. If the hub does not return to origin using the same path it used before, then you have a problem with your joints. You can adjust screws (I am not very good at this, look for Mike's suggestions in older comments) or do as I did and buy Traxxas joints  (or some rod ends or magnetic joints).

comments.text: Can you please release the source of the new hub? I want to edit it to make a mount for e3d hotend. Currently I have 20mm long spacers and a mounting block which makes the heater block almost in line with the hub (I have glass fiber-silicone tubing to save the hub from deforming. It doesn't even get warm). This way I save some z-height but more importantly I use the fan mount that exists on the hub with a much quieter fan. comments.text: Hey guys
comments.author: Stuartblarg

comments.text:
Hi Stuart,
A couple of things spring to mind. Make sure you separate the end stop wires from the stepper wires. Twist the end stop wires together along their length. Twisted pairs are a lot less susceptible to picking up noise.
Make sure you have pull-ups enabled for the end stops. and wire the end stops normally closed.
These will all help to reduce the chance of false triggering of the end stops.
If you're RAMPS is getting hot try reducing the current to the stepper motors. If you haven't used a voltmeter to set the Vref of the drivers to a known value then this is a good place to start. Remember the current rating on a stepper mortor is the maximum allowable current. You don't have to set it that high.50 or 70% of that is often plenty of torque and makes the machine quieter too.
comments.author: Stuartblarg

comments.text: It's 125mm.  All that setting does is set the size of the circular grid on the screen.
comments.author: MikeP-NZ

comments.text: Well that was a lot simpler than I expected, I had the endstop wires and the motor wires wrapped together. After unwrapping them they are working fine again so thanks heaps for that.

comments.author: turuncu

comments.text:
This is a vital piece of information and I am sorry if it comes too late. I thought I had written it in the instructions but it appears not.
The key is "don't drill the holes in the clevis or the pivot arms any larger than 2.5mm. The holes need to be a tight fit on the M3 bolts. You should be screwing the bolts through the plastic. This tight fit is critical to the printer working accurately.

comments.text: How tight should the carriages hold on to the towers? Currently, mine slide off around 3cm down and stop when i release them. Nothing is connected to the carriages yet. Feels like they make too much noise.
comments.author: turuncu

comments.text:
The method I used for setting the tension was to press my thumb against one of the outer bearings and roll the carriage. If I could easily stop the rotation of the bearing and cause it to slide on the tube then it is too loose.
You don't want excessive preload on the bearings. without belts or arms attached it should have very little rolling resistance.
It should certainly fall under its own weight when vertical. I haven't checked but I would expect it to move under its own weight with just a shallow incline. Don't forget that there needs to be a washer between the bearings and the carriage. and the washer size given in the BOM is important. Larger washer sizes may not work properly.
comments.author: turuncu

comments.text:
Thanks for answering.
I follow your drawings as close as possible. The problem is my parts were printed with 3 different printers and 5 different plastics so it is hard to get the dimensions right. It seems like I need to increase scale a little bit because the carriage cannot slide more than 5cm under its own weight.
comments.author: MikeP-NZ

comments.text:
That doesn't sound right. My carriages had a bit of play on the tube before you tighten the preload screws
No part of the carriage plastic should touch the square tube. Only the bearings should touch the square tube.
The bolt holding each of the 8 bearings in the carriage should be tight. Before you fit the carriage on to the tube check that each bearing is completely free to spin without rubbing on anything.
comments.author: turuncu

comments.text: I set the scale 98% and printed one. All 8 bearings touch the tube all the time. It won't fall under its weight but it is very easy to get it moving, certainly not a problem for the steppers. Then I tried 99%. It slides way easier almost like free fall but only 6 bearings can touch the tube at a time. It feels very loose. I like the first one way better. It seems like a need something that is in the middle.
comments.author: MikeP-NZ

comments.text: You should be printing at 100%.  The carriage should be loose on the tube until you do up the preload bolt. The preload bolt flexes the side of the carriage through the live hinge to control the bearing pressure. If you print at 98% then the spacing and offset of the arm mounts will be wrong too.
comments.author: turuncu

comments.text: I decreased the minimum number of perimeters and set the scale to 100%. Now everything is perfect.

comments.text:
You would be better off if you hunt down the GT2 or S2M profile belt. There's plenty of online retailers selling it and on ebay.
The belt connection on the carriage won't work as intended with the 3M belt and you'll need a 12 or 14 tooth pulley for the 3M belt.
comments.author: turuncu

comments.text: i bought 16 teeth pulleys (why did you say 12 or 14? i thought more is better.) as for the carriage, my prusa i3 which was designed for t2.5 works very well although it was not intended. i hope that 3m belts will work. otherwise i will need to get creative with them.
comments.author: MikeP-NZ

comments.text: My design calls for 20 tooth pulleys with 2mm pitch.  which would be 13.3 teeth on a 3mm pitch so the nearest pulley would be a 12 or a 14 tooth pulley.  More teeth will give you a higher speed at the cost of lower resolution.  You may also have problems with the idler pulley because it has a small diameter you may have noise or vibration issues as the teeth roll over it.  It MAY work just fine but I know the GT2 belt will work better.
comments.author: turuncu

This is by far my best 3D model ever. My wife wanted me to create
for her a holiday lantern with snow flakes. Well I took it one step
further and created a lantern that you can mix and match different
panels. I've created a few sets initially. Leave comments abou
t new panels you'd like me to create and I'll upload them. I really
hope you all enjoy this lantern.
FYI - I'm using a 3 inch high tea light that I bought at TJ max. It flickers like a candle. I've uploaded pictures for you to check it out.
Update: I added a tea light shroud for people who can't find the 3 inch tea lights. It's just an open cylinder that will surround your tea light. You obviously will have to print it in a PLA/ABS that is white or clear.
http://youtu.be/n14yuSX7idk

Print out the base and then select 4 panels of your liking. I will be adding more panels as requests come in. Print the top and add your favorite Tea Light or other bulb type illumination (do not use real candles unless your remove the top.
I printed on my Da Vinci Duo at .2 resolution and 25% infill.

are very delicate. I used a scrapper carefully when the print
was completely cooled.

title: Tank, Shuttle Bay Doors, Front Body

description.text:
Here are the body parts to finish up the tanks front end. The gear box and arms to open the doors is under "Tank servo door opener mechanism" in my things. All of this stuff goes with all of the other tank parts in my things to build a complete tank.
I spent hours sanding and fitting these to fit right, but it turned out really cool. Worth the effort. Here is a You Tube Video of the door working https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vqUzjV5_Pv4&list=UUCjC4uorEyPqZ48rLtGJbHQ
The one door (287) is 2.87" long and fits in all 6 places. Drill the screw holes out accordingly. Will have more info in the instructions.
Front cowls are made to fit on a piece of Aluminum channel on front of tank. The suspension block fits in the channel also, and holds a standard size MG996 180 degree servo, for opening the shuttle bay doors with gear drive and arms. The loops on top of the suspension block are for the front track tensioners to swing on with arms and springs. The holes in the middle cowls are so I can get a hex key wrench in to adjust the track tension. Pictures of tensioners are in the "front Idler sprocket and hubs", in my things.
Had a hard time printing some of these, some will have extra support that can be broken away when finished printing. Some of them are just too tall and the support collapsed. The extra support helped hold up the regular support.
Will have a drill diagram shortly. Still working on Battery placement, they hit the doors standing straight up like I want them. So there will be some alternate doors with clearance, and battery mounts coming soon. Still have the rotating turret to do yet, so stay tuned.

The doors all fit together and hinge with the same 15x1 1/2" brad nails that hold the track together with heads cut off. It is almost impossible to print the 287 doors straight. I used a piece of sandpaper on a flat surface to sand down the bottom of door so they are straight. Run a file in the grove for the frame to get lines straight and give clearance for frame. Can bend the brad nails a little at hinges if needed. File down the hinge area to fit. Door are .287" wide, drill holes to place hinges on side rails right at the door joints .150" down from frame top. Sand down the top of the corners of door so top of door if fairly flat. If you sand the door joints in a slight rounded angle you can control how the doors lay on the top by how tight the screw is holding the doors together. Drill the doors so you can get the screw in from the back starting with the door fronts. Drill .120" through .089" for screw to thread toward front of tank.
Front cowls and doors fit together with #4x3/8" and #4x1/2" screws. Front cowls have holes for T1 3/4 LED Lights held in place by plastic LED holders from Radio shack. Clamps screw to bottom of front cowl to clamp to aluminum channel. Suspension block holds standard servo for door opener. It is place back far enough to get the centering gear box in "Door opener mechanism" listing in my things. The mid cowls screw on to the suspension block and hole in frame. Place nails in mid cowl to use as hinge for door assembly. Slide the doors in and out of tank on those nails. Drill the front cowl to .073" so brad is tight fitting and hinges at .076-.078" to swing. Weight to fit doors to other parts until you have the doors fitting right and moving freely. Then fit to other parts to doors so you have a nice fit at the cracks around door. Set up the door linkage like in the photos using #4x1/4 screws and small washer with .180" center. More instructions in the door mechanism listing.
Patients yields results. Have fun!

If you are having trouble with the 1/4" shafts on the arms and stuff. I found something that works really good on them. It is a 1/4" wood plug cutter. It is used to cut round dots out of wood and works perfectly to cut down a 1/4" 3d printed shaft of any kind. these are what they look like http://www.amazon.com/Wolfcraft-3-Piece-Plug-Cutters/dp/B00C7W9TGA/ref=sr_1_9?ie=UTF8&qid=1438116807&sr=8-9&keywords=plug+cutter
I use them by hand, you have to start them carefully, but once they start it cuts the shaft round and true down as long as you have the depth for on the cutter. Very hand little tool for 3D printing mechanical parts.

I designed this case for a Crius GPS NEO-6 module (v3.1) as I couldn't find any published designs that fitted.
This case is for a module pcb of approx 40.5 x 40.5 x 1.0 mm.
There are corner pillars in the base for attaching the module if not using the lid.
If using the lid, the pcb is held in place between the pillars and the skirt of the lid.

I printed mine from white ABS at a layer height of 0.4mm.
PWR & FIX LED's shine through the side of the case well enough to be seen.
As the thickness of the lid is only 1mm there shouldn't be any noticable signal attenuation but I designed the case to have the option of using with or without the lid. The lid is a tight snap fit but best to use a dab of glue to ensure it won't come off.

title: Minimalistc FPV Board Cam Servo Gimbal for SK450

description.text:
A very minimalistic servo gimbal for FPV camera. Tilt axis is first to allow looking around while looking down (for precision landing for instance). Alu gear/arm servo would be best, but it seems rigid enough using plasting 9g servos.
I have used M2x12 scres and M2 nut to mount the servos.
There're special cutouts for servo horns for better and more rigid mounting.
A short video showing it in action: http://youtu.be/yxJc5YWcxTU http://youtu.be/uGauL8hi4LE
Frame mount is for SK450
Pan/yaw is about 45deg in each direction, you may want to modify your servo and get rid of one of the mounts to get wider angles.

description.text:
Printable rugged headlamp; includes lamp housing, helmet mount, and battery pack.   
Update 7-1-2015: Added new housing with recessed hinge; added beefier helmet mount; added individual .stls and new complete build file

Print parameters:
Material ABS
Layer .2
Infill 100%
Shells 3
Raft No!!! Print directly to build plate!
Supports Yes Print time on my Rep 2x: 4h23m
I have added "drawn in" rafts and supports so that you can print directly to the build plate. Remove supports, clean up parts, use a twist drill to clean out holes.
I highly recommend doing an acetone vapor bath on all of the parts before you assemble. This will strengthen and help seal out water and moisture.....plus it gives it a nice glossy finish! If you don't understand what the parts are on the list, you may not want to attempt this build!!! PARTS LIST:
3 1 watt star mounted leds
3 20mm compatible optics
3 20mm optic holders
1 driver board
1 1/2" barrel, panel mount style push button switch - preferably IP67 rated
1 switch boot - if applicable
1 standard 3mm Red LED - for battery status indicator(if driver board has option)
1 aluminium heatsink - diameter 25.4mm, thickness 1.6mm
1 2-conductor power cable - approximately 5mm diameter
1 connector for headlamp cable
2 connectors for battery and charger cables
2 PG7 plastic cable glands
1 4-40 x 1 Socket Head Cap Screw 18-8 Stainless

last file update: 11.04.2015 A multipurpose Extruder for 3.00mm filaments. You can use it as bowden or direct extruder.
  • It's compatible with over 40 hotends
  • There are several tools and adapters included
  • Has optimized geometry and variants for square nut and hexagon nut fastening.
    • You get a really precise description for our extruder here: http://wiki.stoutwind.de/doku.php?id=stoutwinds-rampage-universal-single-extruder The extruder development and creation of the description/build information took several weeks and more than 300 hours (including research, development, sorting, photo shooting, rendering, texting, validating, ...) .
    It's build from ground up, inspired by Greg's wade reloaded extruder and many similar constructions. It has optical identic features but when you look inside you will see many differences and bonus/comfort features. It's worth to look deeper into.
    In the gallery you can see different compability examples for E3D-v6, Hexagon and Sunburn hotends. You can install each type:
  • groove mount
  • thread mount
  • flat mount
  • cylindric mount
    • Rampage works with a lot of well known printers. Because the flat base of Rampage has two long variable hole slots you can mount whatever you want. Please see also "instructions" page for some more details about production/usage. For Download just use the latest zipped version. 1.12.12 also includes a pre-placement of parts (for the lazy guys) Nominal filament diameter for good extrusion: min 2,4mm up to 3,2mm; if you need more space for bigger filaments just drill out a bit recent updated files include manual!

You can read the complete guide for our extruder at the given link:
http://wiki.stoutwind.de/doku.php?id=stoutwinds-rampage-universal-single-extruder for english readers there will be an english translation soon. For now please just use translation by google:
https://translate.google.de/translate?sl=de&tl=en&js=y&prev=_t&hl=de&ie=UTF-8&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwiki.stoutwind.de%2Fdoku.php%3Fid%3Dstoutwinds-rampage-universal-single-extruder&edit-text=
There you find bill of material, installation, step rate calculation, firmware configuration, software manipulation for parameters, downloads and many many more!

Small cell phone spectrometer that can be easily printed. Made by students from Onehunga High School in the Photon Factory at the University of Auckland.

Snap a DVD apart using a blade and cut a piece big enough to cover the angled entrance. Hot glue the lid on top of the main body. Hot glue the DVD grating onto the angled entrance with the grating side facing away from the outside. Using a blade cut a slit 1cm high in aluminium foil and hot glue on the entrance.  
Place the grating ontop of your camera and point the slit at a light source.  
Tip - Often the camera will over expose you can avoid this by reflecting it off a surface and collecting a spectrum from the scattered light.

remixed_from.author: LeFabShop
remixed_from.title: Maker Faire Robot Action Figure (Single file)

title: Baburu, The bubble bot - Robot action figure (1 piece print)

description.text:
Meet Baburu, the bubble bot! I loved the design for the Maker Faire Robot Action Figure and something just struck me where I had to open up my CAD software and see if I could create my own robot in this one piece style.
Here is that creation. Note - I scaled included STL to 110% (see instructions for details) Update - uploaded a lower poly model. The high poly count was causing chatter on the neck joint.

He is pretty straightforward. I printed him with my usual settings I use for about everything(this is close to default settings) and sliced with Simplify3d. no support needed. Takes about 4 to 6 hours depending on settings.  
I scaled the included STL up to 110% - he will print at 100 but I found i got better adhesion of the knee joint this way. The big gold print was 150% - he likes to fall over cause he is so heavy.  
I have found that the biggest failure point I had was bed Tramming. If the bed was too far away things wouldn't stick, if it was too close, things started fusing together at the first layer. Plus I kept getting in too much of a hurry.  
The clearance is .3mm for all parts except the neck, which is .5. It seemed to need a bit more clearance due to the way STL handles circles.   
I usually print in PLA, but I did try some old ABS I had laying around  and the robot with the mostly black background is an ABS print. The first layer got stuck together in a few places and I cut them loose with a razor, and after that he functioned just fine. He does have some less than fine finish in some of the overhangs, but I don't know if I had good settings or not so YMMV.

A simple piece to make the stakes a little more visible. Just add between the stake portion and the head.  Completely optional and compatible with my other stakes. I've included a flat version that should print a little easier. I printed the original as a group of four for cooling and a health brim.

Here are two variations of a melted LEGO brick in standard size. I've also included one of the designs in twice standard size (DUPLO). These should be printed with support at the angles shown in the SLA files. This way the bricks will be printed parallel to the build plate and will look the best.  
Update 11/23/14: I've added improved versions of these bricks with slightly thicker bases that are easier to print and finish.  
Update 12/9/14: The V2 file names now correctly match the files.

Infill = 20%

Feedrate = 40

Temperature = 220C

A strain relief that is mounted on the extruder motor. It keeps the extruder wires nice and tidy too! Requires no disassembly.

Print 1x usr_main and 4x usr_tips. You will also need 4x M3 nuts and bolts, and 3 zip ties.   
Push the nuts into the nut traps and screw in the bolts. screw the tips onto the ends of the bolts. Pull apart the two ends of the main piece and thread the motor wires through. zip tie shut the two ends of the main piece and fit it over the motor. Tighten bolts until it stops moving (don't over-tighten).  
If it doesn't fit, flip it over.

I really love the voronoi-designs so I decided to make my own. The pattern on the diagonals is taken from the speaker stand because I cant use OpenSCAD.
I made 2 versions, one has a 90Â° angle between the diagonals, but I don't like this design so much.
I also included blank pieces so you can create your own design.

• Choose the design you want to make
  • Cut it out of 3mm material. You can vary as you like it, I like the combination of wooden diagonals and black acrylic.
  • Glue everything together, starting with the diagonals which you should then attach to the vertical piece. At last glue it to the bottom.
  • Use it!

This cover is used to protect the motor connector and wiring passing through the hollow center shaft of the motor. It is attached over the motor mount using the existing screws.

Ensure that the screws still thread securely with the cover in place. If not, use slightly longer M3 x 0.5 screws, taking care not to damage the internal motor windings.

My wife wanted something screwed to the wall, but then again, she doesn't repair the drywall. So, a counter-top Thing is it. The toothbrushes are just resting there in the open air, so that there is lots of circulation around them. The weight of their batteries keep them in place. The bottom comes a bit forward of the top, keeping the center of gravity such that it will not topple over, even with the toothbrushes in place.
This thing is designed heavy-duty, hence the 5mm walls.
Printed in White PLA at a whopping 225 degrees. This specific batch of PLA is like that. Or, possibly, my thermostat is way off. Wouldn't surprise me. 25% infill.

author: _sOnGoKu_

description.text:
This printer was designed as part of an architecture design studio at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute led by Francis Bitonti and Xuedi Chen. As a team of four we studied a Rostock Mini Pro deltabot kit, and from there designed our own larger printer with a paste extruder. In addition to scaling the original design of the deltabot, our extruder is powered by an air compressor which pushes material through a vessel situated above the printer down to the extruder nozzle. This end barb can be interchanged to different sizes and geometries. Also, the print bed has the ability to be removed and replaced.
Firmware
  • Arduino: http://arduino.cc/en/Main/Software
  • Repetier: http://www.repetier.com/
    Team: Amanda Turner, Jane Pao, Peini Chen, Pu Pang

Mechanical Parts:
  • ⅛” + ¼” MDF
  • ¼” x 3 ft steel rods
  • ½” x 3 ft steel rods
  • ¼” Acrylic Platform
  • ⅛" + #4 Machine Screws
  • ¼” Linear Ball Bearing
  • 3 Timing Belts 2mm pitch
  • 3 Aluminum GT2 Timing Pulley - 6mm Belt - 36 Tooth - 5mm Bore
  • ½” Fiberglass Arms
  • Zip-Ties
    Electronics:
  • 3D Printer Controller Kit RAMPS 1.4
  • Arduino-Compatible Mega 2560 R3
  • 5pcs A4988 StepStick Compatible Stepper Motor Driver with
  • Heatsink For Arduino RepRap
  • 3 Endstop Microswitches
  • Electronic wire
  • Electronical Tape
  • Sunkee 100x Dupont Jumper Wire Cable Female Pin Connector 2.54mm
  • Dupont Connector Housing Female 4 plugs
  • Nema 17 Stepper Motor
    Extruder:
  • Air Compressor (Regulator with Blow off, ON/OFF Valve, Connector to compressor)
  • ⅜” Vinyl Tube
  • ¼” Brass Bard
  • 1 ½” Male Threaded Connection
  • ¼” Male Threaded Connection
  • 2” Male Threaded Connection
  • 2” Female Threaded Connection
  • ¼” 2 way barb

comments.text: Good looking printer. Very clever to move the weight of the vessel off of the effector.
comments.author: Duplicat
